awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Computer Science for All: Researcher Practitioner Partnerships Workshops (CS for All: RPP), Chicago and Los Angeles
awd_abstract_narration:
Northwestern University proposes to provide logistic and travel support for two workshops (one in Chicago, the other in Los Angeles) that will give technical assistance on designing and implementing effective researcher-practitioner partnerships (RPPs) that aim to bring sustainable, scalable and equitable computer science (CS) education to preK-12 schools. Participating teams will include education researchers and preK-12 practitioners (teachers, administrators, and counselors), possibly augmented with other community, foundation, policy, and industry partners. Through the course of the workshop, they will begin to co-design the goals, metrics, and implementations, that they will need to  strengthen the capacity of their schools to produce successful CS education outcomes for diverse groups of students, educated by different teachers from varied organizational contexts. 

The Principal Investigator, directs the Office of Community Education Partnerships (OCEP) in the School of Education and Social Policy at Northwestern University. OCEP will handle all the event logistics for 160 participants, including but not limited to website design and hosting, registration, arranging meeting room space, catering, and A/V support, and conducting reimbursement for travel costs for participants. The content and delivery of the workshop will be planned and delivered by the Research + Practice Collaboratory centered at the University of Washington.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

por.por_cntn:
Northwestern's Office of Community Education Partnerships (OCEP), led by PIs Nichole Pinkard and Amy D. Pratt, partnered with the Research + Practice Collaboratory to design and implement  two, RPP workshops (Los Angeles, California and Chicago, Illinois).  The OCEP team was specifically responsible for coordinating the on-the-ground logistics and planning for the workshops. This includes the design, development, and hosting of the workshop website, participant registration, procuring meeting space, arranging lodging, meals, travel plans, and audio-visual support, and handling travel and hotel reimbursements and payments to vendors. Northwestern staff were budgeted to ensure efficient and timely preparation, execution, and follow up on the workshops and to support the Research + Practice Collaboratory team in the delivery of the workshops.

Significant Results:

Both workshops exceeded the goal of 80 participants each. A complete list of workshop participants is included with this report. Lists of RPP teams for both workshops are also included.

The Los Angeles workshop was held on February 5 and 6, 2018 and had 89 participants.

  •  74 participants were from RPP teams comprised of researchers and practitioners from higher education institutions, the K-12 community, and other educational organizations, in addition to 9 workshop speakers; 3 NSF program officers; and 3 members from the planning team from Northwestern and UCLA.
  • There was a total of 22 RPP Teams in attendance. 11 had submitted an RPP proposal to NSF in 2017 and 2 were awarded a CSforAll RPP grant from that cycle.

The Chicago workshop was held on March 1 and 2, 2018 and had 106 participants.

  • 88 participants were from RPP teams comprised of researchers and practitioners from higher education institutions, the K-12 community, and other educational organizations, in addition to 9 workshop speakers; 5 NSF program officers; and 4 members from the planning team from Northwestern and UCLA.
  • There was a total of 25 RPP Teams in attendance. 11 had submitted an RPP proposal to NSF in 2017 and 1 was awarded a CSforAll RPP grant from that cycle.

Last Modified: 06/06/2023
Modified by: Nichole Pinkard
